Russia has also sought to increase its influence in theMiddle East, most significantly through military intervention in theSyrian civil war.Cyberwarfareandairspaceviolations, along with electoral interference, have been used to increase perceptions of Russian power.[286]Russia's relations withneighbouring Ukraineand the Western world—especially theUnited States, theEuropean Union, theUnited NationsandNATO—have collapsed; especially following the start of the Russo-Ukrainian War in 2014 and the consequent escalation in 2022.[287][288]Relations between Russia and China have significantlystrengthened bilaterally and economically; due to shared political interests.[289]Turkeyand Russia share a complexstrategic, energy, and defence relationship.[290]Russia maintainscordial relationswith Iran, as it is a strategic and economic ally.[291]Russia has also increasingly pushed to expand its influence across theArctic,[292]Asia-Pacific,[293]Africa,[294]the Middle East,[295]and Latin America.[296]According to theEconomist Intelligence Unit, two-thirds of the world's population live in countries such asChinaorIndiathat are neutral or leaning towards Russia.[297]", "TheRussian Armed Forcesare divided into theGround Forces, theNavy, and theAerospace Forces—and there are also two independent arms of service: theStrategic Missile Troopsand theAirborne Troops.[10]As of 2021[update], the military have around a million active-duty personnel, which is the world'sfifth-largest, and about 2–20 millionreserve personnel.[299][300]It is mandatory for all male citizens aged 18–27 to bedraftedfor a year of service in the Armed Forces.[10]", "Russia is among the fiverecognisednuclear-weapons states, with the world'slargest stockpile of nuclear weapons; over half of the world's nuclear weapons are owned by Russia.[301]Russia possesses the second-largest fleet ofballistic missile submarines,[302]and is one of the only three countries operatingstrategic bombers.[303]Russia maintains the world'sthird-highest military expenditure, spending $86.4 billion in 2022, corresponding to around 4.1% of its GDP.[304]In 2021 it was the world'ssecond-largest arms exporter, and had a large and entirely indigenousdefence industry, producing most of its own military equipment.[305]", 'Violations ofhuman rights in Russiahave been increasingly criticised by leading democracy andhuman rights groups. In particular,Amnesty InternationalandHuman Rights Watchsay that Russia is not democratic and allows few political rights and civil liberties to its citizens.[307][308]', 'Since 2004,Freedom Househas ranked Russia as "not free" in itsFreedom in the Worldsurvey.[309]Since 2011, theEconomist Intelligence Unithas ranked Russia as an "authoritarian regime" in itsDemocracy Index, ranking it 146th out of 167 countries in 2022.[310]In regards tomedia freedom, Russia was ranked 155th out of 180 countries inReporters Without Borders\'Press Freedom Indexfor 2022.[311]The Russian government has been widely criticised by political dissidents andhuman rights activistsforunfair elections,[312]crackdowns onopposition political parties and protests,[313][314]persecution of non-governmental organisationsand enforced suppression andkillings of independent journalists,[315][316][317]andcensorshipof mass media andinternet.[318]', 'Muslims, especiallySalafis, have faced persecution in Russia.[319][320]To quash theinsurgency in the North Caucasus, Russian authorities have been accused of indiscriminate killings,[321]arrests, forced disappearances, and torture of civilians.[322][323]InDagestan, some Salafis along with facing government harassment based on their appearance, have had their homes blown up in counterinsurgency operations.[324][325]Chechens andIngushinRussian prisonsreportedly take more abuse than other ethnic groups.[326]During the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Russia has set upfiltration campswhere many Ukrainians are subjected to abuses and forcibly sent to Russia; the camps have been compared tothose used in the Chechen Wars.[327][328]Political repression also increased following the start of the invasion, withlaws adoptedthat establish punishments for "discrediting" the armed forces.[329]', 'Russia has introduced several restrictions onLGBT rights, including a 2020 ban on same-sex marriage and the designation of LGBT+ organisations such as theRussian LGBT Networkas "foreign agents".[330][331]', "Russia'sautocratic[332]political system has been variously described as akleptocracy,[333]anoligarchy,[334]and aplutocracy.[335]It was the lowest rated European country inTransparency International'sCorruption Perceptions Indexfor 2021, ranking 136th out of 180 countries.[336]Russia has a long history of corruption, which is seen as a significant problem.[337]It impacts various sectors, including the economy,[338]business,[339]public administration,[340]law enforcement,[341]healthcare,[342][343]education,[344]and the military.[345]", 'The primary and fundamental statement of laws in Russia is theConstitution of the Russian Federation. Statutes, like theRussian Civil Codeand theRussian Criminal Code, are the predominant legal sources of Russian law.[346][347][348]', "Russia has the world's second largest illegal arms trade market, after the United States, is ranked first in Europe and 32nd globally in the Global Organized Crime Index, and is among the countries with the highest number of people in prison.[349][350][351]", "Russia has amarket economy, with enormous natural resources, particularlyoilandnatural gas.[353]It has the world'sninth-largest economyby nominal GDP and thesixth-largestbyPPP. The largeservice sectoraccounts for 62% of total GDP, followed by theindustrial sector(32%), while theagricultural sectoris the smallest, making up only 5% of total GDP.[10]Russia has a low officialunemployment rateof 4.1%.[354]Itsforeign exchange reservesare the world'sfifth-largest, worth $540 billion.[355]It has a labour force of roughly 70 million, which is the world'ssixth-largest.[356]", "Russia is the world'sthirteenth-largest exporterand the21st-largest importer.[357][358]It relies heavily on revenues from oil and gas-related taxes and export tariffs, which accounted for 45% of Russia's federal budget revenues in January 2022,[359]and up to 60% of its exports in 2019.[360]Russia has one of thelowest levels of external debtamong major economies,[361]although itsinequality of household income and wealthis one of the highest among developed countries.[362]High regional disparity is also an issue.[363][364]", 'After over a decade of post-Soviet rapid economic growth, backed by high oil-prices and a surge in foreign exchange reserves and investment,[195]Russia\'s economy was damaged following the start of the Russo-Ukrainian War and the annexation of Crimea in 2014, due to the first wave ofWestern sanctions being imposed.[365]In the aftermath of the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the country has facedrevamped sanctions and corporate boycotts,[366]becoming the most sanctioned country in the world,[367]in a move described as an "all-out economic and financial war" to isolate the Russian economy from the Western financial system.[206]Due to theimpact, the Russian government has stopped publishing a raft of economic data since April 2022.[368]Economists suggest the sanctions will have a long-term effect over the Russian economy.[369]', "Railway transport in Russiais mostly under the control of the state-runRussian Railways. The total length of common-used railway tracks is the world'sthird-longest, and exceeds 87,000\xa0km (54,100\xa0mi).[371]As of 2016[update], Russia has the world'sfifth-largest road network, with 1.5 million\xa0km of roads,[372]while its road density is among the world's lowest.[373]Russia's inland waterways are the world'slongest, and total 102,000\xa0km (63,380\xa0mi).[374]AmongRussia's 1,218 airports,[375]thebusiestisSheremetyevo International Airportin Moscow. Russia's largest port is thePort of NovorossiyskinKrasnodar Kraialong the Black Sea.[376]", "Russia was widely described as anenergy superpower.[377]It has the world's largestproven gas reserves,[378]the second-largestcoal reserves,[379]the eighth-largestoil reserves,[380]and the largestoil shale reservesin Europe.[381]Russia is also the world'sleading natural gas exporter,[382]thesecond-largest natural gas producer,[383]and the second-largest oilproducerandexporter.[384][385]Russia's oil and gas production led to deep economic relationships with theEuropean Union, China, andformer SovietandEastern Bloc states.[386][387]For example, over the last decade, Russia's share of supplies to totalEuropean Union(including the United Kingdom) gas demand increased from 25% in 2009 to 32% in the weeks before theRussian invasion of Ukrainein February 2022.[387]", "In the mid-2000s, the share of the oil and gas sector in GDP was around 20%, and in 2013 it was 20–21% of GDP.[388]The share of oil and gas in Russia's exports (about 50%) and federal budget revenues (about 50%) is large, and the dynamics of Russia's GDP are highly dependent on oil and gas prices,[389]but the share in GDP is much less than 50%. According to the first such comprehensive assessment published by the Russian statistics agency Rosstat in 2021, the maximum total share of the oil and gas sector in Russia's GDP, including extraction, refining, transport, sale of oil and gas, all goods and services used, and all supporting activities, amounts to 19.2% in 2019 and 15.2% in 2020. This is comparable to the share of GDP in Norway and Kazakhstan. It is much lower than the share of GDP in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.[390][391][392][393][394]", "Russia ratified theParis Agreementin 2019.[395]Greenhouse gas emissions by Russiaare the world'sfourth-largest.[396]Russia is the world's fourth-largestelectricity producer.[397]It was also the world's first country to develop civilian nuclear power, and to construct the world'sfirst nuclear power plant.[398]Russia was also the world's fourth-largestnuclear energy producerin 2019,[399]and was the fifth-largesthydroelectric producerin 2021.[400]", 'Russia\'s agriculture sector contributes about 5% of the country\'s total GDP, although the sector employs about one-eighth of the total labour force.[401]It has the world\'sthird-largest cultivated area, at 1,265,267 square kilometres (488,522\xa0sq\xa0mi). However, due to the harshness of its environment, about 13.1% of its land isagricultural,[10]and only 7.4% of its land isarable.[402]The country\'s agricultural land is considered part of the "breadbasket" of Europe.[403]More than one-third of the sown area is devoted to fodder crops, and the remaining farmland is devoted toindustrial crops, vegetables, and fruits.[401]The main product of Russian farming has always been grain, which occupies considerably more than half of the cropland.[401]Russia is the world\'slargest exporter of wheat,[404][405]thelargest producer of barleyandbuckwheat, among the largest exporters ofmaizeandsunflower oil, and the leading producer offertilizer.[406]', "Various analysts ofclimate change adaptationforesee large opportunities for Russian agriculture during the rest of the 21st century as arability increases in Siberia, which would lead to both internal and external migration to the region.[407]Owing to its large coastline along three oceans and twelve marginal seas, Russiamaintainsthe world'ssixth-largest fishing industry; capturing nearly 5 million tons of fish in 2018.[408]It is home to the world's finest caviar, thebeluga; and produces about one-third of all canned fish, and some one-fourth of the world's total fresh and frozen fish.[401]", "Russia spent about 1% of its GDP onresearch and developmentin 2019, with the world'stenth-highest budget.[409]It also ranked tenth worldwide in the number of scientific publications in 2020, with roughly 1.3 million papers.[410]Since 1904,Nobel Prizewere awarded to 26 Soviets and Russians inphysics,chemistry,medicine,economy,literatureandpeace.[411]Russia ranked 51st in theGlobal Innovation Indexin 2023, down from 45th in 2021.[412][413]", "Since the times ofNikolay Lobachevsky, who pioneered thenon-Euclidean geometry, andPafnuty Chebyshev, a prominent tutor; Russianmathematiciansbecame among the world's most influential.[414]Dmitry Mendeleevinvented thePeriodic table, the main framework of modernchemistry.[415]Nine Soviet and Russian mathematicians have been awarded with theFields Medal.Grigori Perelmanwas offered the first ever ClayMillennium Prize ProblemsAward for his final proof of thePoincaré conjecturein 2002, as well as the Fields Medal in 2006.[416]", 'Alexander Popovwas among theinventors of radio,[417]whileNikolai BasovandAlexander Prokhorovwere co-inventors oflaserandmaser.[418]Oleg Losevmade crucial contributions in the field ofsemiconductor junctions, and discoveredlight-emitting diodes.[419]Vladimir Vernadskyis considered one of the founders ofgeochemistry,biogeochemistry, andradiogeology.[420]Élie Metchnikoffis known for his groundbreaking research inimmunology.[421]Ivan Pavlovis known chiefly for his work inclassical conditioning.[422]Lev Landaumade fundamental contributions to many areas oftheoretical physics.[423]', 'Nikolai Vavilovwas best known for having identified thecentresof origin ofcultivatedplants.[424]Trofim Lysenkowas known mainly forLysenkoism.[425]Many famous Russian scientists and inventors wereémigrés.Igor Sikorskywas anaviation pioneer.[426]Vladimir Zworykinwas the inventor of theiconoscopeandkinescopetelevision systems.[427]Theodosius Dobzhanskywas the central figure in the field ofevolutionary biologyfor his work in shaping themodern synthesis.[428]George Gamowwas one of the foremost advocates of theBig Bangtheory.[429]', "Roscosmosis Russia's national space agency. The country's achievements in the field ofspace technologyandspace explorationcan be traced back toKonstantin Tsiolkovsky, the father of theoreticalastronautics, whose works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such asSergey Korolyov,Valentin Glushko, and many others who contributed to the success of theSoviet space programin the early stages of theSpace Raceand beyond.[430]:\u200a6–7,\u200a333", 'In 1957, the first Earth-orbiting artificialsatellite,Sputnik\xa01, was launched. In 1961, the first human trip into space was successfully made byYuri Gagarin. Many other Soviet and Russianspace exploration recordsensued. In 1963,Valentina Tereshkovabecame the first and youngestwoman in space, having flown a solo mission onVostok 6.[431]In 1965,Alexei Leonovbecame the first human to conduct aspacewalk, exiting thespace capsuleduringVoskhod 2.[432]', "In 1957,Laika, aSoviet space dog, became the first animal to orbit the Earth, aboardSputnik 2.[433]In 1966,Luna\xa09became the first spacecraft to achieve a survivable landing on acelestial body, theMoon.[434]In 1968,Zond 5brought the first Earthlings (two tortoises and other life forms) to circumnavigate the Moon.[435]In 1970,Venera\xa07became the first spacecraft to land on another planet,Venus.[436]In 1971,Mars\xa03became the first spacecraft to land onMars.[437]:\u200a34–60During the same period,Lunokhod 1became the firstspace exploration rover,[438]whileSalyut\xa01became the world's firstspace station.[439]", "Russia had 172 active satellites in space in April 2022, the world's third-highest.[440]Between the final flight of theSpace first of theLuna-GlobMoon exploration programme.[442]", "According to theWorld Tourism Organization, Russia was the sixteenth-most visited country in the world, and the tenth-most visited country in Europe, in 2018, with over 24.6 million visits.[443]According toFederal Agency for Tourism, the number of inbound trips of foreign citizens to Russia amounted to 24.4 million in 2019.[444]Russia's international tourism receipts in 2018 amounted to $11.6 billion.[443]In 2019, travel and tourism accounted for about 4.8% of country's total GDP.[445]", "Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around theGolden Ring of Russia, atheme routeof ancient Russian cities, cruises on large rivers such as the Volga, hikes on mountain ranges such as theCaucasus Mountains,[446]and journeys on the famousTrans-Siberian Railway.[447]Russia's most visited and popular landmarks includeRed Square, thePeterhof Palace, theKazan Kremlin, theTrinity Lavra of St. Sergiusand Lake Baikal.[448]", "Moscow, the nation's cosmopolitan capital and historic core, is a bustlingmegacity. It retains its classical and Soviet-era architecture; while boasting high art, world class ballet, andmodern skyscrapers.[449]Saint Petersburg, the Imperial capital, is famous for its classical architecture, cathedrals, museums and theatres,white nights, criss-crossing rivers and numerous canals.[450]Russia is famed worldwide for its rich museums, such as theState Russian, theState Hermitage, and theTretyakov Gallery; and for theatres such as theBolshoiand theMariinsky. TheMoscow Kremlinand theSaint Basil's Cathedralare among the cultural landmarks of Russia.[451]", "Russia is one of the world'smost sparsely populatedandurbanisedcountries,[10]with the vast majority of its population concentrated within itswestern part.[452]It had a population of 142.8 million according to the2010 census,[453]which rose to 144.7 million as of the2021 census(excluding Crimea and Sevastopol).[15]Russia is themost populous countryin Europe, and the world'sninth most populous country, with apopulation densityof 8 inhabitants\xa0per square kilometre (21 inhabitants/sq\xa0mi).[454]", "Since the 1990s, Russia'sdeath ratehas exceeded itsbirth rate, which some analysts have called ademographic crisis.[455]In 2022, thetotal fertility rateacross Russia was estimated to be 1.42 children born per woman,[456]which is below the replacement rate of 2.1, and is one of the world'slowest fertility rates.[457]Subsequently, the nation has one of the world'soldest populations, with a median age of 40.3 years.[10]In 2009, it recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen years, and subsequently experienced annual population growth due to decliningdeath rates, increasedbirth rates, and increased immigration.[458]", "However, since 2020, Russia's population gains have been reversed, as excessive deaths from theCOVID-19 pandemicresulted in its largest peacetime decline in history.[459]Following theRussian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the demographic crisis in the country has deepened,[460]as the country has reportedly suffered high military fatalities while facing renewedbrain drainandhuman capital flightcaused by Western mass-sanctions and boycotts.[461]", "Russia is amultinational statewith many subnational entities associated with different minorities.[462]There are over193 ethnic groups nationwide. In the 2010 census, roughly 81% of the population were ethnicRussians, and the remaining 19% of the population were ethnic minorities;[463]while over four-fifths of Russia's population was ofEuropean descent—of whom the vast majority wereSlavs,[464]with a substantial minority ofFinno-UgricandGermanic peoples.[465][466]According to the United Nations, Russia'simmigrant populationis the world's third-largest, numbering over 11.6 million;[467]most of which are frompost-Soviet states, mainly fromCentral Asia.[468]", "Russian is theofficialand the predominantly spoken language in Russia.[3]It is the most spokennative languagein Europe, the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the world's most widely spokenSlavic language.[471]Russian is one of two official languages aboard theInternational Space Station,[472]as well as one of the sixofficial languages of the United Nations.[471]", "Russia is amultilingualnation; approximately 100–150 minority languages are spoken across the country.[473][474]According to theRussian Census of 2010, 137.5\xa0million across the country spoke Russian, 4.3\xa0million spokeTatar, and 1.1\xa0million spokeUkrainian.[475]The constitution gives the country's individual republics the right toestablish their own state languagesin addition to Russian, as well as guarantee its citizens the right to preserve their native language and to create conditions for its study and development.[476]However, various experts have claimed Russia's linguistic diversity is rapidly declining due tomany languages becoming endangered.[477][478]", 'Russia is asecular stateby constitution, and its largest religion isEastern Orthodox Christianity, chiefly represented by theRussian Orthodox Church.[479]Orthodox Christianity, together withIslam,Buddhism, andPaganism(either preserved orrevived), are recognised by Russian law as the traditional religions of the country, part of its "historical heritage".[480][481]', 'Islam is the second-largest religion in Russia, and is the traditional religion among the majority of thepeoples of the North Caucasus, and among someTurkic peoplesscattered along theVolga-Uralregion.[479]Large populations of Buddhists are found inKalmykia,Buryatia,Zabaykalsky Krai, and they are the vast majority of the population inTuva.[479]Many Russians practise other religions, includingRodnovery(Slavic Neopaganism),[482]Assianism(Scythian Neopaganism),[483]other ethnic Paganisms, and inter-Pagan movements such asRinging Cedars\' Anastasianism,[484]various movements ofHinduism,[485]Siberian shamanism[486]andTengrism, variousNeo-Theosophicalmovements such asRoerichism, and other faiths.[487][488]Some religious minorities have faced oppression and some have been banned in the country;[489]notably, in 2017 theJehovah\'s Witnesseswere outlawed in Russia, facing persecution ever since, after having been declared an "extremist" and "nontraditional" faith.[490]', 'In 2012, the research organisation Sreda, in cooperation with theMinistry of Justice, published the Arena Atlas, an adjunct to the 2010 census, enumerating in detail the religious populations and nationalities of Russia, based on a large-sample country-wide survey. The results showed that 47.3% of Russians declared themselves Christians—including 41% Russian Orthodox, 1.5% simply Orthodox or members of non-Russian Orthodox churches, 4.1% unaffiliated Christians, and less than 1%Old Believers,CatholicsorProtestants—25% werebelievers without affiliation to any specific religion, 13% wereatheists, 6.5% were Muslims,[j]1.2% were followers of "traditional religions honouring gods and ancestors" (Rodnovery, other Paganisms,Siberian shamanismandTengrism), 0.5% were Buddhists, 0.1% werereligious Jewsand 0.1% were Hindus.[479]', "Russia has an adultliteracy rateof 100%,[492]and hascompulsory educationfor a duration of 11 years, exclusively for children aged 7 to 17–18.[493]It grantsfree educationto its citizens by constitution.[494]TheMinistry of Education of Russiais responsible for primary and secondary education, as well as vocational education; while theMinistry of Education and Science of Russiais responsible for science and higher education.[493]Regional authorities regulate education within their jurisdictions within the prevailing framework of federal laws. Russia is among the world's most educated countries, and has thesixth-highest proportionoftertiary-level graduatesin terms of percentage of population, at 62.1%.[495]It spent roughly 4.7% of its GDP on education in 2018.[496]", "Russia'spre-schooleducation system is highly developed and optional,[497]some four-fifths of children aged 3 to 6 attend day nurseries or kindergartens. Primary school is compulsory for eleven years, starting from age 6 to 7, and leads to a basic general education certificate.[493]An additional two or three years of schooling are required for the secondary-level certificate, and some seven-eighths of Russians continue their education past this level.[498]", "Admission to an institute of higher education is selective and highly competitive:[494]first-degree courses usually take five years.[498]The oldest and largestuniversitiesin Russia areMoscow State UniversityandSaint Petersburg State University.[499]There are ten highly prestigiousfederal universitiesacross the country. Russia was the world's fifth-leading destination forinternational studentsin 2019, hosting roughly 300 thousand.[500]", 'Russia, by constitution, guarantees free,universal health carefor all Russian citizens, through a compulsory state health insurance program.[502]TheMinistry of Health of the Russian Federationoversees the Russian public healthcare system, and the sector employs more than two million people. Federal regions also have their own departments of health that oversee local administration. A separate private health insurance plan is needed to access private healthcare in Russia.[503]', "Russia spent 5.65% of its GDP on healthcare in 2019.[504]Its healthcare expenditure is notably lower than other developed nations.[505]Russia has one of the world's most female-biasedsex ratios, with 0.859 males to every female,[10]due to its high malemortality rate.[506]In 2021, the overalllife expectancy in Russiaat birth was 70.06 years (65.51 years for males and 74.51 years for females),[507]and it had a very lowinfant mortality rate(5 per 1,000live births).[508]", "The principal cause of death in Russia are cardiovascular diseases.[509]Obesityis a prevalent health issue in Russia; most adults are overweight or obese.[510]However, Russia's historically highalcohol consumption rateis the biggest health issue in the country,[511]as it remainsone of the world's highest, despite a stark decrease in the last decade.[512]Smokingis another health issue in the country.[513]The country'shigh suicide rate, althoughon the decline,[514]remains a significant social issue.[515]", 'Russianwritersandphilosophershave played an important role in the development ofEuropean literatureand thought.[516][517]The Russians have also greatly influenced classical music,[518]ballet,[519]sport,[520]painting,[521]andcinema.[522]The nation has also made pioneering contributions toscience and technologyandspace exploration.[523][524]', "Russia is home to30 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 19 out of which are cultural; while 27 more sites lie on the tentative list.[525]The large globalRussian diasporahas also played a major role in spreading Russian culture throughout the world. Russia's national symbol, thedouble-headed eagle, dates back to the Tsardom period, and is featured in itscoat of armsandheraldry.[70]TheRussian BearandMother Russiaare often used asnational personificationsof the country.[526][527]Matryoshka dollsare considered a cultural icon of Russia.[528]", 'Russia has eight—public, patriotic, and religious—official holidays.[529]The year starts with New Year\'s Day on 1 January, soon followed byRussian Orthodox Christmason 7 January; the two are the country\'s most popular holidays.[530]Defender of the Fatherland Day, dedicated to men, is celebrated on 23 February.[531]International Women\'s Dayon 8 March, gained momentum in Russia during the Soviet era. The annual celebration of women has become so popular, especially among Russian men, that Moscow\'s flower vendors often see profits of "15 times" more than other holidays.[532]Spring and Labour Day, originally a Soviet era holiday dedicated to workers, is celebrated on 1 May.[533]', "Victory Day, which honours Soviet victory over Nazi Germany and theEnd of World War II in Europe, is celebrated on 9 May as an annuallarge paradein Moscow's Red Square;[534]and marks the famousImmortal Regimentcivil event.[535]Other patriotic holidays includeRussia Dayon 12 June, celebrated to commemorate Russia'sdeclaration of sovereigntyfrom the collapsing Soviet Union;[536]andUnity Dayon 4 November, commemorating the1612 uprisingwhich marked the end of thePolish occupation of Moscow.[537]", 'There are many popular non-public holidays.Old New Yearis celebrated on 14 January.[538]Maslenitsais an ancient and popular East Slavic folk holiday.[539]Cosmonautics Dayon 12 April, in tribute to the first human trip into space.[540]Two major Christian holidays are Easter andTrinity Sunday.[541]', "Early Russian painting is represented iniconsand vibrantfrescos. In the early 15th-century, the master icon painterAndrei Rublevcreated some of Russia's most treasured religious art.[542]TheRussian Academy of Arts, which was established in 1757, to train Russian artists, brought Western techniques of secular painting to Russia.[85]In the 18th century, academiciansIvan Argunov,Dmitry Levitzky,Vladimir Borovikovskybecame influential.[543]The early 19th century saw many prominent paintings byKarl BriullovandAlexander Ivanov, both of whom were known forRomantichistorical canvases.[544][545]Ivan Aivazovsky, another Romantic painter, is considered one of the greatest masters ofmarine art.[546]", 'In the 1860s, a group of criticalrealists(Peredvizhniki), led byIvan Kramskoy,Ilya RepinandVasiliy Perovbroke with the academy, and portrayed the many-sided aspects of social life in paintings.[547]The turn of the 20th century saw the rise ofsymbolism; represented byMikhail VrubelandNicholas Roerich.[548][549]TheRussian avant-gardeflourished from approximately 1890 to 1930; and globally influential artists from this era wereEl Lissitzky,[550]Kazimir Malevich,Natalia Goncharova,Wassily Kandinsky, andMarc Chagall.[551]', 'The history ofRussian architecturebegins with early woodcraft buildings of ancient Slavs, and thechurch architecture of Kievan Rus\'.[552]Following theChristianization of Kievan Rus\', for several centuries it was influenced predominantly byByzantine architecture.[553]Aristotle Fioravantiand other Italian architects broughtRenaissancetrends into Russia.[554]The 16th-century saw the development of the uniquetent-like churches; and theonion domedesign, which is a distinctive feature of Russian architecture.[555]In the 17th-century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow andYaroslavl, gradually paving the way for theNaryshkin baroqueof the 1680s.[556]', "After the reforms of Peter the Great, Russia's architecture became influenced by Western European styles. The 18th-century taste forRococoarchitecture led to thesplendid worksofBartolomeo Rastrelliand his followers. The most influential Russian architects of the eighteenth century;Vasily Bazhenov,Matvey Kazakov, andIvan Starov, created lasting monuments in Moscow and Saint Petersburg and established a base for the more Russian forms that followed.[542]During the reign of Catherine the Great, Saint Petersburg was transformed into an outdoor museum ofNeoclassical architecture.[557]Under Alexander I,Empire stylebecame thede factoarchitectural style.[558]The second half of the 19th-century was dominated by theNeo-ByzantineandRussian Revivalstyle.[559]In early 20th-century,Russian neoclassical revivalbecame a trend.[560]Prevalent styles of the late 20th-century wereArt Nouveau,[561]Constructivism,[562]andSocialist Classicism.[563]", 'Until the 18th-century, music in Russia consisted mainly of church music and folk songs and dances.[564]In the 19th-century, it was defined by the tension between classical composerMikhail Glinkaalong with other members ofThe Mighty Handful, who were later succeeded by theBelyayev circle,[565]and theRussian Musical Societyled by composersAntonandNikolay Rubinstein.[566]The later tradition ofPyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era, was continued into the 20th century bySergei Rachmaninoff. World-renowned composers of the 20th century includeAlexander Scriabin,Alexander Glazunov,[564]Igor Stravinsky,Sergei ProkofievandDmitri Shostakovich, and laterEdison Denisov,Sofia Gubaidulina,[567]Georgy Sviridov,[568]andAlfred Schnittke.[567]', "During the Soviet era,popular musicalso produced a number of renowned figures, such as the twoballadeers—Vladimir VysotskyandBulat Okudzhava,[567]and performers such asAlla Pugacheva.[569]Jazz, even with sanctions from Soviet authorities, flourished and evolved into one of the country's most popular musical forms.[567]By the 1980s,rock musicbecame popular across Russia, and produced bands such asAria,Aquarium,[570]DDT,[571]andKino;[572]the latter's leaderViktor Tsoi, was in particular, a gigantic figure.[573]Pop musichas continued to flourish in Russia since the 1960s, with globally famous acts such ast.A.T.u.[574]", "Russian literatureis considered to be among the world's most influential and developed.[516]It can be traced to theMiddle Ages, when epics and chronicles inOld East Slavicwere composed.[577]By theAge of Enlightenment, literature had grown in importance, with works fromMikhail Lomonosov,Denis Fonvizin,Gavrila Derzhavin, andNikolay Karamzin.[578]From the early 1830s, during theGolden Age of Russian Poetry, literature underwent an astounding golden age in poetry, prose and drama.[579]Romanticismpermitted a flowering of poetic talent:Vasily Zhukovskyand later his protégéAlexander Pushkincame to the fore.[580]Following Pushkin's footsteps, a new generation of poets were born, includingMikhail Lermontov,Nikolay Nekrasov,Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy,Fyodor TyutchevandAfanasy Fet.[578]", 'The first great Russian novelist wasNikolai Gogol.[581]Then cameIvan Turgenev, who mastered both short stories and novels.[582]Fyodor DostoevskyandLeo Tolstoysoon became internationally renowned.Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrinwrote prose satire,[583]whileNikolai Leskovis best remembered for his shorter fiction.[584]In the second half of the centuryAnton Chekhovexcelled in short stories and became a leading dramatist.[585]Other important 19th-century developments included the fabulistIvan Krylov,[586]non-fiction writers such as the criticVissarion Belinsky,[587]and playwrights such asAleksandr GriboyedovandAleksandr Ostrovsky.[588][589]The beginning of the 20th century ranks as theSilver Age of Russian Poetry. This era had poets such asAlexander Blok,Anna Akhmatova,Boris Pasternak, andKonstantin Balmont.[590]It also produced some first-rate novelists and short-story writers, such asAleksandr Kuprin, Nobel Prize winnerIvan Bunin,Leonid Andreyev,Yevgeny Zamyatin,Dmitry MerezhkovskyandAndrei Bely.[578]', 'After the Russian Revolution of 1917, Russian literature split into Soviet andwhite émigréparts. In the 1930s,Socialist realismbecame the predominant trend in Russia. Its leading figure wasMaxim Gorky, who laid the foundations of this style.[591]Mikhail Bulgakovwas one of the leading writers of the Soviet era.[592]Nikolay Ostrovsky\'s novelHow the Steel Was Temperedhas been among the most successful works of Russian literature. Influential émigré writers includeVladimir Nabokov,[593]andIsaac Asimov; who was considered one of the "Big Three" science fiction writers.[594]Some writers dared to oppose Soviet ideology, such as Nobel Prize-winning novelistAleksandr Solzhenitsyn, who wrote about life in the Gulag camps.[595]', 'Russian philosophyhas been greatly influential.Alexander Herzenis known as one of the fathers ofagrarianpopulism.[596]Mikhail Bakuninis referred to as the father ofanarchism.[597]Peter Kropotkinwas the most important theorist ofanarcho-communism.[598]Mikhail Bakhtin\'s writings have significantly inspired scholars.[599]Helena Blavatskygained international following as the leading theoretician ofTheosophy, and co-founded theTheosophical Society.[600]Vladimir Lenin, a major revolutionary, developed a variant of communism known asLeninism.[601]Leon Trotsky, on the other hand, foundedTrotskyism.[602]Alexander Zinovievwas a prominent philosopher in the second half of the 20th century.[603]Aleksandr Dugin, known for hisfascistviews, has been regarded as the "guru of geopolitics".[604]', 'Russian cuisine has been formed by climate, cultural and religious traditions, and the vast geography of the nation; and it shares similarities with the cuisines of its neighbouring countries. Crops ofrye, wheat,barley, andmilletprovide the ingredients for various breads,pancakesand cereals, as well as for many drinks.Bread, of many varieties,[605]is very popular across Russia.[606]Flavourful soups and stews includeshchi,borsch,ukha,solyanka, andokroshka.Smetana(a heavysour cream) andmayonnaiseare often added to soups and salads.[607][608]Pirozhki,[609]blini,[610]andsyrnikiare native types ofpancakes.[611]Beef Stroganoff,[612]:\u200a266Chicken Kiev,[612]:\u200a320pelmeni,[613]andshashlykare popular meat dishes.[614]Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls (golubtsy) usually filled with meat.[615]Salads includeOlivier salad,[616]vinegret,[617]anddressed herring.[618]', "Russia'snational non-alcoholic drinkiskvass,[619]and the national alcoholic drink isvodka; its production in Russia (and elsewhere) dates back to the 14th century.[620]The country has the world's highest vodka consumption,[621]whilebeeris the most popular alcoholic beverage.[622]Winehas become increasingly popular in Russia in the 21st century.[623]Tea has been popular in Russiafor centuries.[624]", "There are 400 news agencies in Russia, among which the largest internationally operating areTASS,RIA Novosti,Sputnik, andInterfax.[626]Televisionis the most popular medium in Russia.[627]Among the 3,000 licensed radio stations nationwide, notable ones includeRadio Rossii,Vesti FM,Echo of Moscow,Radio Mayak, andRusskoye Radio. Of the 16,000 registered newspapers,Argumenty i Fakty,Komsomolskaya Pravda,Rossiyskaya Gazeta,Izvestia, andMoskovskij Komsomoletsare popular. State-runChannel OneandRussia-1are the leading news channels, whileRTis the flagship of Russia's international media operations.[627]Russia has thelargest video gaming marketin Europe, with over 65 million players nationwide.[628]", 'Russian and laterSoviet cinemawas a hotbed of invention, resulting in world-renowned films such asThe Battleship Potemkin, which was named thegreatest film of all timeat theBrussels World\'s Fairin 1958.[629][630]Soviet-era filmmakers, most notablySergei EisensteinandAndrei Tarkovsky, would go on to become among of the world\'s most innovative and influential directors.[631][632]Eisenstein was a student ofLev Kuleshov, who developed the groundbreakingSoviet montage theoryof film editing at the world\'s first film school, theAll-Union Institute of Cinematography.[633]Dziga Vertov\'s "Kino-Eye" theory had a huge impact on the development of documentary filmmaking and cinema realism.[634]Many Soviet socialist realism films were artistically successful, includingChapaev,The Cranes Are Flying, andBallad of a Soldier.[522]', "The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema.[522]The comedies ofEldar RyazanovandLeonid Gaidaiof that time were immensely popular, with many of the catchphrases still in use today.[635][636]In 1961–68Sergey Bondarchukdirected anOscar-winningfilm adaptationof Leo Tolstoy's epicWar and Peace, which wasthe most expensive filmmade in the Soviet Union.[522]In 1969,Vladimir Motyl'sWhite Sun of the Desertwas released, a very popular film in a genre ofostern; the film is traditionally watched bycosmonautsbefore any trip into space.[637]After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Russian cinema industry suffered large losses—however, since the late 2000s, it has seen growth once again, and continues to expand.[638]", 'Footballis the most popular sport in Russia.[640]TheSoviet Union national football teambecame the first European champions by winningEuro 1960,[641]and reached the finals ofEuro 1988.[642]Russian clubsCSKA MoscowandZenit Saint Petersburgwon theUEFA Cupin 2005 and 2008.[643][644]TheRussian national football teamreached the semi-finals ofEuro 2008.[645]Russia was the host nation for the2017 FIFA Confederations Cup,[646]and the2018 FIFA World Cup.[647]However, Russian teams are currently suspended from FIFA and UEFA competitions.[648]', "Ice hockeyis very popular in Russia, and theSoviet national ice hockey teamdominated the sport internationally throughout its existence.[520]Bandyis Russia's national sport, and it has historically been the highest-achieving country in the sport.[649]TheRussian national basketball teamwon theEuroBasket 2007,[650]and the Russian basketball clubPBC CSKA Moscowis among the most successful European basketball teams.[651]The annualFormula OneRussian Grand Prixwas held at theSochi Autodromin theSochi Olympic Park, until its termination following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022.[652][653]", "Historically,Russian athleteshave been one of the most successful contenders in theOlympic Games.[520]Russia is the leading nation inrhythmic gymnastics; and Russiansynchronised swimmingis considered to be the world's best.[654]Figure skatingis another popular sport in Russia, especiallypair skatingandice dancing.[655]Russia has produced numerous prominent tennis players.[656]Chessis also a widely popular pastime in the nation, with many of the world's top chess players being Russian for decades.[657]The1980 Summer Olympic Gameswere held in Moscow,[658]and the2014 Winter Olympicsand the2014 Winter Paralympicswere hosted in Sochi.[659][660]However, Russia has also had 43Olympic medalsstripped from its athletes due todoping violations, which is the most of any country, and nearly a third of the global total.[661]", 'This article incorporates text from afree contentwork.  Licensed under CC BY 4.0 (license statement/permission). Text taken fromFrequently Asked Questions on Energy Security\u200b,International Energy Agency, the International Energy Agency.', 'Government', 'General information', 'Other', '66°N94°E\ufeff / \ufeff66°N 94°E\ufeff /66; 94']
